Least Squares

Find x⃗\vec{x}x﻿ such that Ax⃗≈b⃗A\vec{x} \approx \vec{b}Ax≈b﻿ by minimizing ∣∣Ax⃗−b⃗∣∣2||A\vec{x}-\vec{b}||^2∣∣Ax−b∣∣2﻿

It is relatively easy to minimize the squared norm rather than the norm because now the squared norm is differentiable and convex(any local minimum is a global minimum)

Solution:

We can either derive the solution by minimizing derivative of ∣∣Ax⃗−b∣∣2||A\vec{x}-b||^2∣∣Ax−b∣∣2﻿ or projecting b⃗\vec{b}b﻿ to Col(A)Col(A)Col(A)﻿ - column space of matrix AAA﻿.

Intuition of method 2 (projection) ⇒ projection of b⃗\vec{b}b﻿ onto Col(A)Col(A)Col(A)﻿ would form a right angle triangle and we know that perpendicular distances are the shortest.

We derive by:

Fundamental Theorem of Linear Algebra

The SVD Decomposition of A can be written as

where the diagonal values of Σ\SigmaΣ﻿ are called singular values of AAA﻿ ⇒ they are actually eigenvalues of both A⊤A,AA⊤A^{\top}A, AA^{\top}A⊤A,AA⊤﻿

The orthonormal eigenvectors of A⊤AA^{\top}AA⊤A﻿ are called right singular vectors of AAA﻿ and they rest inside columns of VVV﻿, in the order such that they corresponds to the square root of their eigenvalues in Σ\SigmaΣ﻿

The orthonormal eigenvectors of AA⊤AA ^{\top}AA⊤﻿ are called left singular vectors of AAA﻿ and they rest inside columns of UUU﻿, in the order such that they corresponds to the square root of their eigenvalues in Σ\SigmaΣ﻿

Graphical Interpretation: U,V→Rotation / ReflectionU, V \rightarrow \text{Rotation / Reflection}U,V→Rotation / Reflection﻿, Σ→Scaling\Sigma \rightarrow ScalingΣ→Scaling﻿

To understand this graphical representation of a general vector, think about decomposing the vector x⃗\vec{x}x﻿ into eigenvectors of VVV﻿

And think about how V⊤V^{\top}V⊤﻿ first projects x⃗\vec{x}x﻿ onto every eigenvector of A⊤AA^{\top}AA⊤A﻿, then scales them, then transforms them as if they were in coordinates of AA⊤AA^{\top}AA⊤﻿

Convex Set

Set CCC﻿ is convex if any line segment joining any two points in the set is contained in the set.

OR

Set CCC﻿ is convex if any convex combination of points inside the set is contained inside the set

Seperating Hyperplane Theorem

If there exists two disjoint convex sets C,DC,DC,D﻿ then there exists a hyperplane a⃗⊤x⃗=b\vec{a}^\top \vec{x} = ba⊤x=b﻿ that seperates the two sets.

  1. g(λ⃗,ν⃗)g(\vec{\lambda}, \vec{\nu})g(λ,ν)﻿ is a lower bound on the primal optimal p∗p^*p∗﻿

KKT Conditions (Karush-Kuhn-Tucker Conditions)

KKT Condition Part I (Necessary Conditions)

  • Consider primal optimal x⃗∗\vec{x}^*x∗﻿ and dual optimal (λ⃗∗,ν⃗∗)(\vec{\lambda}^*, \vec{\nu}^*)(λ∗,ν∗)﻿
  • Assume strong duality holds d∗=g(λ⃗∗,ν⃗∗)=p∗=f0(x⃗∗)d^* = g(\vec{\lambda}^*, \vec{\nu}^*) = p^* = f_0(\vec{x}^*)d∗=g(λ∗,ν∗)=p∗=f0​(x∗)﻿
  • No assumption on convexity
  • differentiable f0,fi,hif_0, f_i, h_if0​,fi​,hi​﻿

x⃗∗,λ⃗∗,ν⃗∗\vec{x}^*, \vec{\lambda}^*, \vec{\nu}^*x∗,λ∗,ν∗﻿ optimality implies

  1. ∀i∈[1,m],fi(x⃗∗)≤0\forall i \in [1,m], f_i(\vec{x}^*) \le 0∀i∈[1,m],fi​(x∗)≤0﻿
    1. feasible set
  1. ∀i∈[1,p],hi(x⃗∗)=0\forall i \in [1,p], h_i(\vec{x}^*) = 0∀i∈[1,p],hi​(x∗)=0﻿
    1. feasible set
  1. ∀i∈[1,m],λi∗≥0\forall i \in [1,m], \lambda_i^* \ge 0∀i∈[1,m],λi∗​≥0﻿
    1. constraint on λ\lambdaλ﻿, dual feasible set
  1. ∀i∈[1,m],λi∗⋅fi(x⃗∗)=0\forall i \in [1,m], \lambda_i^* \cdot f_i(\vec{x}^*) = 0∀i∈[1,m],λi∗​⋅fi​(x∗)=0﻿
    1. complementary slackness
  1. ∇f0(x⃗∗)+∑λi∗∇fi(x⃗∗)+∑νi∗∇hi(x⃗∗)=0\nabla f_0(\vec{x}^*) + \sum \lambda_i^* \nabla f_i(\vec{x}^*) + \sum \nu_i^* \nabla h_i(\vec{x}^*) = 0∇f0​(x∗)+∑λi∗​∇fi​(x∗)+∑νi∗​∇hi​(x∗)=0﻿
    1. Gradient of lagrangian is equal to 0
    1. We proved earlier that x⃗∗=min⁡x⃗L(x⃗,λ⃗∗,ν⃗∗)\vec{x}^* = \min_{\vec{x}} L(\vec{x}, \vec{\lambda}^*, \vec{\nu}^*)x∗=minx​L(x,λ∗,ν∗)﻿
    1. implied by “the main theorem”

KKT Condition Part II (Sufficient Condition)

  • Convex problems
    • f0,fif_0, f_if0​,fi​﻿ are convex
    • hih_ihi​﻿ are affine
  • Strong Duality

x~,λ~,ν~\tilde{x}, \tilde{\lambda}, \tilde{\nu}x~,λ~,ν~﻿ are points that satisfy

  1. ∀i∈[1,m],fi(x~)≤0\forall i \in [1,m], f_i(\tilde{x}) \le 0∀i∈[1,m],fi​(x~)≤0﻿
  1. ∀i∈[1,p],hi(x~)=0\forall i \in [1,p], h_i(\tilde{x}) = 0∀i∈[1,p],hi​(x~)=0﻿
  1. ∀i∈[1,m],λ~i≥0\forall i \in [1,m], \tilde{\lambda}_i \ge 0∀i∈[1,m],λ~i​≥0﻿
  1. ∀i∈[1,m],λ~i⋅fi(x~)=0\forall i \in [1,m], \tilde{\lambda}_i \cdot f_i(\tilde{x}) = 0∀i∈[1,m],λ~i​⋅fi​(x~)=0﻿
  1. ∇f0(x~)+∑λ~i∇fi(x~)+∑ν~i∇hi(x~)=0\nabla f_0(\tilde{x}) + \sum \tilde{\lambda}_i \nabla f_i(\tilde{x}) + \sum \tilde{\nu}_i \nabla h_i(\tilde{x}) = 0∇f0​(x~)+∑λ~i​∇fi​(x~)+∑ν~i​∇hi​(x~)=0﻿

Polyhedron

  • Set {x⃗∈Rn∣Ax⃗≥b⃗:A∈Rm×n,b⃗∈Rm}\{ \vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n | A\vec{x} \ge \vec{b} : A \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}, \vec{b} \in \mathbb{R}^m \}{x∈Rn∣Ax≥b:A∈Rm×n,b∈Rm}﻿
  • “Standard Form” Set {x⃗∈Rl∣Cx⃗=d⃗,x⃗≥0}\{ \vec{x} \in \mathbb{R}^l | C\vec{x} = \vec{d}, \vec{x} \ge 0 \}{x∈Rl∣Cx=d,x≥0}﻿

Extreme Point of Polyhedron PPP﻿:

  • We cannot find two vectors for x⃗\vec{x}x﻿ as a convex combination of other two points y⃗\vec{y}y​﻿ and z⃗\vec{z}z﻿

Fact:

  • PPP﻿ has an extreme point iff P does not contain a line

If we assume

  • PPP﻿ has an extreme point
  • Opt. solution exists and is finite

Then:

  • There exists an optimal solution that is an extreme point of PPP﻿

Proof:

Let QQQ﻿ be the set of all possible solutions

  • QQQ﻿ is also a polyhedron (expressed with inequality constraints
  • Q⊆PQ \sube PQ⊆P﻿, so QQQ﻿ cannot contain a line.
    • QQQ﻿ has an extreme point

If uuu﻿ is a vertex of QQQ﻿, how do we prove uuu﻿ is a vertex of PPP﻿

Suppose for contradiction that uuu﻿ is not a vertex of PPP﻿

then ∃y,z∈P,y,z≠u\exists y, z \in P, y, z \ne u∃y,z∈P,y,z=u﻿ and λy+(1−λ)z=u,λ∈(0,1)\lambda y + (1-\lambda) z = u, \lambda \in (0,1)λy+(1−λ)z=u,λ∈(0,1)﻿

We know c⊤u=p∗c^\top u = p^*c⊤u=p∗﻿ ⇒ λc⊤y+(1−λ)c⊤z=c⊤u=p∗\lambda c^\top y + (1-\lambda) c^\top z = c^\top u = p^*λc⊤y+(1−λ)c⊤z=c⊤u=p∗﻿

We know since p∗p^*p∗﻿ is the optimal,

By the above strict equation, we infer

So now y,z∈Qy, z \in Qy,z∈Q﻿

But uuu﻿ is a vertex in QQQ﻿, we have a contradiction!

Therefore uuu﻿ must be a vertex in PPP﻿.

Cones

Cone: Set of points C⊆RnC \sube \mathbb{R}^nC⊆Rn﻿ is a cone iff ∀x⃗∈C,∀α≥0,αx⃗∈C\forall \vec{x} \in C, \forall \alpha \ge 0, \alpha \vec{x} \in C∀x∈C,∀α≥0,αx∈C﻿.

  • Convex Cone
    • A cone CCC﻿ is convex iff ∀θ1,θ2≥0,θ1x⃗1+θ2x⃗2∈C\forall \theta_1, \theta_2 \ge 0, \theta_1 \vec{x}_1 + \theta_2 \vec{x}_2 \in C∀θ1​,θ2​≥0,θ1​x1​+θ2​x2​∈C﻿
  • Polyhedral Cone
    • C={(x⃗,t)∣Ax⃗≤b⃗t,t∈R,t≥0}C = \{ (\vec{x},t) | A\vec{x} \le \vec{b}t, t \in \mathbb{R}, t \ge 0 \}C={(x,t)∣Ax≤bt,t∈R,t≥0}﻿
  • Ellipsoidal Cone
    • Equation for Ellipse
      • x⊤Px+q⊤x+r≤0,P>0x^\top P x + q^\top x + r \le 0, P > 0x⊤Px+q⊤x+r≤0,P>0﻿ OR
      • ∣∣Ax+b∣∣22≤c2||Ax+b||_2^2 \le c^2∣∣Ax+b∣∣22​≤c2﻿, x⊤A⊤Ax+2b⊤Ax+b⊤b−c2≤0x^\top A^\top A x + 2 b^\top A x + b^\top b -c^2 \le 0x⊤A⊤Ax+2b⊤Ax+b⊤b−c2≤0﻿
    • Ellipsoidal Cone Equation
      • C={(x,t);∣∣Ax+bt∣∣2≤ct}C = \{ (x,t) ; ||Ax + bt||_2 \le ct \}C={(x,t);∣∣Ax+bt∣∣2​≤ct}﻿
      • (αx,αt)∈C,∀α≥0,(x,t)∈C(\alpha x, \alpha t) \in C, \forall \alpha \ge 0, (x,t) \in C(αx,αt)∈C,∀α≥0,(x,t)∈C﻿
    • Special Case:
      • Second-Order Cone
        • C⊂Rn+1,C={(x⃗,t);∣∣x⃗∣∣2≤t}C \sub \mathbb{R}^{n+1}, C = \{ (\vec{x}, t) ; ||\vec{x}||_2 \le t \}C⊂Rn+1,C={(x,t);∣∣x∣∣2​≤t}﻿

Seperating Hyperplane

A seperating hyperplane of data is

such that

  • If w⃗⊤x⃗i+b>0\vec{w}^\top \vec{x}_i + b > 0w⊤xi​+b>0﻿ then yi=+1y_i = +1yi​=+1﻿
  • If w⃗⊤x⃗i+b<0\vec{w}^\top \vec{x}_i + b < 0w⊤xi​+b<0﻿ then yi=−1y_i = -1yi​=−1﻿

Define distance to hyperplane from a class to be the minimum of all distances of all points in the class to the hyperplane.

So formulation of SVM:

If (m,w⃗,b)(m, \vec{w}, b)(m,w,b)﻿ is a solution, then (m,αw⃗,αb)(m, \alpha \vec{w}, \alpha b)(m,αw,αb)﻿ is also a solution ⇒ there’s unlimited representation, so let’s impose norm on w⃗\vec{w}w﻿!

This is called a hard-margin SVM

We also have “Soft-margin SVM”
